titleStmt.title: The trend of Epstein-Barr virus DNA loads and CD8<sup>+</sup> T lymphocyte numbers can predict the prognosis of pediatric liver transplant recipients with PTLD

sourceDesc.bibl: Kedi Wang, Dongjiang Xu, Yan Gao, Kaihui Ma, Wen Zhao. (2024). The trend of Epstein-Barr virus DNA loads and CD8<sup>+</sup> T lymphocyte numbers can predict the prognosis of pediatric liver transplant recipients with PTLD. Journal of Laboratory Medicine, 49(1), 38-45. DOI: 10.1515/labmed-2024-0081

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

grobid.training.segmentation

text.front:
Adv. Nonlinear Stud. 2024; 24(1): 178-188
Research Article
Special Issue: In honor of Joel Spruck
Tobias Holck Colding and William P. Minicozzi II*
Eigenvalue lower bounds and splitting
for modified Ricci flow
https://doi.org/10.1515/ans-2022-0083
Received February 3, 2023; accepted June 21, 2023; published online March 8, 2024
Abstract: We prove sharp lower bounds for eigenvalues of the drift Laplacian for a modified Ricci flow. The
modified Ricci flow is a system of coupled equations for a metric and weighted volume that plays an important
role in Ricci flow. We will also show that there is a splitting theorem in the case of equality.
Keywords: Ricci flow; geometric flows; eigenvalue; drift laplacian
text.body:
1 Introduction
A metric g and function f on a manifold M induce a weighted L 2 norm â€–uâ€– 2
L 2 = âˆ« u 2 e -f , a corresponding
weighted energy, and a natural elliptic operator
îˆ¸ = Î” -âˆ‡ âˆ‡ f
(1.1)
called the drift Laplacian. When M is compact, or g is complete with a log Sobolev inequality and âˆ« e -f dğ‘£ g < âˆ,
then îˆ¸ has eigenvalues
0 = ğœ† 0 (t) < ğœ† 1 (t) â‰¤ â€¢ â€¢ â€¢ â†’ âˆ
(1.2)
that carry important geometric information.
The triple (M, g, f ) is a gradient shrinking Ricci soliton (or shrinker) if g and f satisfy
Hess f + Ric =
1
2
g,
(1.3)
where Ric is the Ricci curvature for the metric g, [1]-[3]. Ricci shrinkers appear as singularities of Ricci flow.
For shrinkers, there is a sharp lower bound ğœ† 1 â‰¥ 1
2 , where equality is achieved if and only if the shrinker splits
off a line, [4]. In Ref. [5], we showed that if a shrinker almost splits on one scale, then it also almost splits on
larger scales; this was called propagation of almost splitting. See Refs. [6], [7] for related results and Ref. [8] for
an asymptotic splitting theorem for shrinkers.
text.front:
Dedicated to our friend Joel Spruck.
The authors were partially supported by NSF DMS Grants 2104349 and 2005345.
*Corresponding author: William P. Minicozzi II, Department of Mathematics, MIT, 77 Massachusetts Avenue, Cambridge, MA 02139-
4307, USA, E-mail: minicozz@math.mit.edu
Tobias Holck Colding, Department of Mathematics, MIT, 77 Massachusetts Avenue, Cambridge, MA 02139-4307, USA,
E-mail: colding@math.mit.edu
Open Access. Â© 2024 the author(s), published by De Gruyter.
This work is licensed under the Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International
License.
text.note: T. H. Colding and W. P. Minicozzi: Splitting for modified Ricci flow -
text.body:
We are interested here in an analogous lower bound and splitting for flows. The parabolic analog of the
shrinker equation is the modified (or rescaled) Ricci flow. In this case, the metric g and function f evolve by
g t = g -2 Hess f -2 Ric,
(1.4)
f t =
n
2
-S -Î” f.
(1.5)
These coupled equations are important in Ricci flow since they describe, up to scaling and diffeomorphisms,
flows arising from blowing up at a singularity; see, e.g., Refs. [9]-[11]. They also arise as the negative gradient
flow for Perelman's entropy functional, [12], [13]. A static solution of (1.4) is a shrinker.
Easy examples show that there is no uniform lower bound for ğœ† 1 on a modified Ricci flow, even if the flow is
ancient, but instead some additional condition is necessary. The next theorems give generalizations for modified
Ricci flows.
Theorem 1.6. If M is compact, g, f satisfy (1.4) and (1.5) for t âˆˆ [t 0 , âˆ), and there is a sequence t j â†’ âˆ so that
(M, g(t j ), f (t j )) converges to a shrinker, then ğœ† 1 (t) > 1
2 for all t.
Furthermore, we get sharp upper bounds for the evolution of ğœ† k (t) for all of the eigenvalues:
Theorem 1.7. If M is compact, g, f satisfy (1.4) and (1.5), and k â‰¥ 1, then:
-If ğœ† k (t 0 ) < 1
2 , then ğœ† k (t) < ğœ† k (t 0 ) for t 0 < t and
ğœ† k (t) â‰¤
ğœ† k (t 0 )
2 ğœ† k (t 0 )
(
1 -e t-t 0
) + e t-t 0 .
(1.6)
-If ğœ† k (t 0 ) = 1
2 , then ğœ† k (t) â‰¤ 1
2 for all t 0 â‰¤ t.
-If 1
2 < ğœ† k (t 0 ), then (1.6) applies for all t < t 0 + log 2 ğœ† k (t 0 )
2 ğœ† k (t 0 )-1 .
The assumption t < t 0 + log 2 ğœ† k (t 0 )
2 ğœ† k (t 0 )-1 in the last case is equivalent to assuming that the denominator in (1.6) is
positive.
The previous theorems generalize to a wide class of non-compact weighted spaces, requiring only that all
integrations by parts involved make sense and integrals converge. We will assume this in the following theorem;
see Theorem 3.1 for a precise description of the splitting.
Theorem 1.9. Suppose that (1.4) and (1.5) hold for t âˆˆ [t 0 , âˆ). If ğœ† k (t 0 ) = 1
2 for some k â‰¥ 1 and ğœ† 1 (t 1 ) â‰¥ 1
2 , then g(t)
and f split off an R k factor for t âˆˆ [t 0 , t 1 ].
When a modified flow arises from blowing up at a singularity, then the possible long-time limits of the flow
describe the possible tangent flows at the singularity. Thus, the uniqueness of blowups question for a Ricci flow
is translated into the uniqueness of limits for the modified Ricci flow, cf. [14] for mean curvature flow and Refs.
[15]-[17] for uniqueness of closed blowups for Ricci flows.
2 Differential inequalities
The eigenvalues ğœ† k of îˆ¸ vary continuously in t, but are not necessarily differentiable. Differentiability can fail
because of the multiplicity of the eigenvalues. However, the variational characterization of the eigenvalues gives
a natural upper bound for ğœ† k (t) in the future. This bound implies an upper bound for ğœ† â€²
k (t) in the sense of the
limsup of forward difference quotients. We collect some elementary consequences of such upper bounds.
text.note: -T. H. Colding and W. P. Minicozzi: Splitting for modified Ricci flow

Lemma 1.7. Suppose that h(t) â‰¥ 0 satisfies h â€² (t) â‰¤ h(t) (h(t) -1) in the sense of (2.1).
-If h(t 0 ) < 1, then h(t) < h(t 0 ) for all t > t 0 .

We will prove the second claim by contradiction. Suppose therefore that there exists t 2 > t 0 with h(t 2 ) > 1.
Let t 1 be the maximal value of t âˆˆ [t 0 , t 2 ] with h(t) = 1 (this exists since h is continuous and h(t 0 ) = 1). It follows
that t 1 < t 2 , h(t 1 ) = 1 and h â‰¥ 1 on [t 1 , t 2 ]. In particular, h â€² â‰¤ 0 on [t 1 , t 2 ]. Therefore, Lemma 1.3 gives that h â‰¤
h(t 1 ) = 1 on [t 1 , t 2 ], contradicting that h(t 2 ) > 1 and, thus, completing the argument.

In this section, we will assume that (M, g, f ) satisfies (1.4) and (1.5). The f -divergence of a vector field V is defined

3.2 Sharpness
The next example shows that the estimates in Theorem 1.7 are sharp. Define the function f and metric g on R n
by

It is easy to see that f and g satisfy the modified Ricci flow equations (1.4) and (1.5). Notice that if u(t 0 ) > 1,
then u is growing and is defined for all t (i.e., it is eternal). On the other hand, when u(t 0 ) < 1, then u shrinks to
zero in finite time -but the solution is ancient.

â–¡
4 Splitting theorem
We will prove the splitting theorem, Theorem 1.9, under the assumption that the integrations by parts are justi-
fied and the integrals converge. For instance, when M has finite weighted volume and a log Sobolev inequality,
then Proposition 1 in Ref. [4] (cf. [9]) guarantees that îˆ¸ has discrete eigenvalues going to infinity with finite
multiplicity and with eigenfunctions in W 1,2 .
We start with a more precise statement of the splitting:
text.note: -T. H. Colding and W. P. Minicozzi: Splitting for modified Ricci flow

text.div:
Author contributions: The authors have accepted responsibility for the entire content of this manuscript and
approved its submission.
Competing interests: The authors state no conflict of interest.
Research funding: The authors were partially supported by NSF DMS Grants 2104349 and 2005345.
text.listBibl:
References
[1] H. D. Cao, "Recent progress on Ricci solitons," in Recent Advances in Geometric Analysis, Adv. Lect. Math. (ALM), vol. 11, Somerville,
MA, Int. Press, 2010, pp. 1-38.
[2] B. Chow, P. Lu, and L. Ni, Hamilton's Ricci Flow, GSM 77, Providence, RI, AMS, 2006.
[3] R. Hamilton, "The formation of singularities in the Ricci flow," in Surveys in Differential Geometry, vol. II (Cambridge, MA, 1993),
Cambridge, MA, Int. Press, 1995, pp. 7-136.
[4] X. Cheng and D. Zhou, "Eigenvalues of the drifted Laplacian on complete metric measure spaces," Commun. Contemp. Math., vol. 19,
no. 1, p. 1650001, 2017. .
[5] T. H. Colding and W. P. Minicozzi, II, "Singularities of Ricci flow and diffeomorphisms," preprint.
[6] T. H. Colding and W. P. Minicozzi, II, "Singularities and diffeomorphisms," ICCM Not, vol. 10, no. 1, pp. 112-116, 2022. .
[7] T. H. Colding and W. P. Minicozzi II, "Propagation of symmetries for Ricci shrinkers," Adv. Nonlinear Stud., vol. 23, no. 1, pp. 1-8,
2023. .
[8] B. Chow and P. Lu, "On Îº-noncollapsed complete noncompact shrinking gradient Ricci solitons which split at infinity," Math. Ann.,
vol. 366, nos. 3-4, pp. 1195-1206, 2016. .
[9] H.-J. Hein and A. Naber, "New logarithmic Sobolev inequalities and an Ïµ-regularity theorem for the Ricci flow," Commun. Pure Appl.
Math., vol. 67, no. 9, pp. 1543-1561, 2014. .
text.note: -T. H. Colding and W. P. Minicozzi: Splitting for modified Ricci flow
text.listBibl:
[10] C. Mantegazza and R. MÃ¼ller, "Perelman's entropy functional at type I singularities of the Ricci flow," J. Reine Angewandte Math.,
vol. 703, pp. 173-199, 2015, .
[11] S. Sun and Y. Wang, "On the KÃ¤hler-Ricci flow near a KÃ¤hler-Einstein metric," J. Reine Angewandte Math., vol. 699, pp. 143-158, 2015, .
[12] G. Perelman, "The entropy formula for the Ricci flow and its geometric applications," Preprint, 2002. arXiv:math/0211159.
[13] P. Topping, Lectures on the Ricci Flow. London Math. Society Lecture Note Series, 325, Cambridge, Cambridge University Press, 2006.
[14] T. H. Colding and W. P. Minicozzi II, "Uniqueness of blowups and Lojasiewicz inequalities," Ann. Math., vol. 2, no. 1, pp. 221-285,
2015. .
[15] R. Bamler, "Structure theory of non-collapsed limits of Ricci flows," 2020. https://arxiv.org/abs/2009.03243.
[16] P.-Y. Chan, Z. Ma, and Y. Zhang, "On Ricci flows with closed and smooth tangent flows," arXiv:2109.14763, 2021.
[17] P.-Y. Chan, Z. Ma, and Y. Zhang, "The rate of F-convergence for Ricci flows with closed and smooth tangent flows," J. Geom. Anal.,
vol. 32, no. 12, 2022, Art. no. 293. .
[18] T. H. Colding and W. P. Minicozzi II, "Complexity of parabolic systems," Publ. Math. Inst. Hautes Etudes Sci., vol. 132, no. 1, pp.
83-135, 2020. .
